title: 107_s355
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Commemorative Coin Act of 2001". Congress finds that Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. dedicated his life to securing the Nation's principles of liberty and justice, spearheaded the civil rights movement in the 1950s and 1960s, delivered his famous "I Have A Dream" speech at the March on Washington in 1963, and championed nonviolence. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. advocated nonviolent resistance to end segregation and racial discrimination in America, winning the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize. Americans should honor his legacy to achieve equality. Efforts are ongoing to preserve King's personal papers for future study at the Library of Congress. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS.

The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 silver coins, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender.

SEC. 4. SOURCES OF BULLION.

Silver for minting the coins will be obtained from various sources, including stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act.

SEC. 5. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the human rights legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various entities and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility for each quality during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2003. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. The Secretary will promptly pay all surcharges received from the sale of coins issued under this Act to the Library of Congress for purchasing and maintaining historical documents related to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
